awd_titl_txt: Development of Divergent Cascade Annulation Reactions for the Synthesis of Malagashanine and Akuamilline Alkaloids
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Simon Blakey of Emory University is developing new reactions that will allow the synthesis of two novel families of bioactive molecules. The development of new methodology, and the demonstrated ability to access multiple classes of natural products that were previously inaccessible, will set the stage for further understanding of the basic biological activities of these molecules. This fundamental research will pave the way for the development of the therapeutic properties implied in ethnomedicine studies that serve as the inspiration for this project, furthering our understanding of malarial resistance to common drug treatments, and potentially providing a road map to new clinical entities.

An outreach program is exploring the narrative of the malagashanine story through a collaboration between the sciences and the arts. The combination illustrates the interplay between disciplines to inform a public audience on cutting edge science and ethical questions arising from the discoveries. Professor Blakey will deliver public lectures at the Atlanta Botanical Garden, and ultimately to broad audiences as part of the Atlanta Science Festival.

The unusual structures of these molecules render them difficult to synthesize with existing methods. To date, no members of either family have been synthesized. To meet the challenge posed by these molecules, and provide significant quantities for further biological study, new reactions and new catalysts to control these reactions are under development. Specifically, a series of stereospecific iminium ion initiated cascade reactions, and novel chiral disulfonamide catalysts will be developed and studied, providing solutions to the synthetic problem posed by the malagashanine and akuamma alkaloids. These studies are expected to culminate in the syntheses of representative molecules from both families.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Overview:The last 50 years have seen amazing advances in the isolation and synthesis of natural products. In many cases, either total synthesis or semi-synthesis has been required to confirm a molecules structure, to understand its properties, and to develop useful products for societal use. Despite these advances, Nature’s ability to surprise, delight and challenge us remains extraordinary. She continues to produce molecules with intriguing properties and structures that defy our existing synthetic capabilities. Such was the case with the malagashanine alkaloids - a family of stereochemically unique strychnos alkaloids presenting a molecular architecture that necessitated the development of new synthetic methodology, and a biological profile that warranted this investment.

 

Intellectual merit: The mark of powerful new methodology is its applicability beyond the synthetic problem for which it was designed. In this project, we developed a series of novel reactions providing an elegant solution to the structural challenge posed by the malagashanine alkaloids. Additionally we evolved this methodology to allow access to an important subclass of the akuamma alkaloids that had until recently, eluded the synthetic community, and to oxygen containing analogues as well. Long term, this fundamental research will pave the way for developing a greater understanding of the biological, and potentially therapeutic properties of these unique molecules.

 

Broader impacts:During the duration of the project, 4 graduate students received expert training and education in chemical research. Two of these students now conduct cutting edge research in the pharmaceutical industry, one student is an expert in scientific patents, and the fourth student is completing their graduate studies. Three of the students associate with groups traditionally underrepresented in the physical science.

Additionally, four students all received their first undergraduate research training while conducting elements of this project. All four students are women, and all matriculated to PhD programs.

The demographics of the students engaged in this project significantly contribute to broadening participation in the chemical sciences.

Beyond the significant scientific advances described above, and the significant educational activities advancing a diverse workforce in the chemical sciences, researchers in this project  met with the public in informal settings to describe the link between basic research, innovation and research in the private sector, and ultimately the partnership between government agencies, academic institutes and industry to generate innovations that contribute to better society in the U.S.A. These informal meetings took place at the Atlanta botanical gardens (as part of the Science Café during “Cocktails in the Garden”, at the Fernbank Science Museum, and at the Atlanta Science Festival. 

 


Last Modified: 05/15/2019
Modified by: Simon B Blakey
